div.l: That down he goth and criede harrow y dye
These clerkes bet him wel ⁊and let him lye
And greythen hem and toke her͗e hors a non
And eke her͗e mele and on her͗e wey þey goon
And atte Mille yet þey toke here cake
Of half a busshel floure ful wel I bake
Thus is þe proude Meller͗e wel I bete
And haþ I lost þe gryndyng of þe whete
And paied for þe soꝑpere eủery dele
Of Aleyn ⁊and of Iohn þat bette him wele
His wif is swyued and his doughter als
Lo swyþe is a Meller͗e to be fals
And þ̉erfore þis proủerbe is seide ful soth
Him þar not wene wel þat yuel doth
A gylour shal him self bi giled be
And god þat sitteth highe in mageste
Saue alle þis companye grete ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quyt þe Meller in my tale
¶ Here begynnyth þe prolog of þe Cookes tale
The cook of london while þe Reue spak
For ioye him þouȝt he clowede him on þe bak

Wel ouȝt a man auysed for to be
Whom þat he brouȝt in to his pⁱriuyte
I pᵃray to god so yeue me sorwen ⁊and care
If eủere · sithen · I hight hogge of ware
Hedde I Meller better I sette a werke

And þ̉erfore if ye vouche saf to here
